conclusion: Relate the measured emf to the average flow velocity
When a conductor of length ℓ moves with velocity v perpendicular to a uniform magnetic field B, the motional (Faraday) emf between its ends is E = B ℓ v.
For the flowmeter the 'conductor' is the column of liquid between the two electrodes M and N.
Its length ℓ is the inner diameter d of the pipe (the electrodes are placed on opposite walls).
The liquid velocity is the average axial velocity v in the pipe.
B is perpendicular to both v and the M–N line.
Thus E = B d v ⟹ v = E ⁄ (B d).
Express the volumetric flow rate Q
The volume that passes the pipe cross-section per unit time equals the cross-sectional area A times the average velocity v: Q = A v.
For a circular pipe of inner diameter d, A = πd² ⁄ 4.
Insert v from (1): Q = (πd² ⁄ 4) × (E ⁄ (B d)) = (πd E) ⁄ (4 B).
The flow rate measured by the electromagnetic flowmeter is Q = π d E / (4 B).

That is, the volume of liquid flowing through the pipe per unit time is directly proportional to the measured emf E and the pipe diameter d, and inversely proportional to the magnetic-field strength B.
